etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in William Foster (b. 1591), Church of England clergyman and writer. From Persian ‘abbāsī from ‘Abbas, the name of Shah Abbas I (reigned 1587–1629) + -ī

definitions: A Persian silver coin (originally weighing approx. 9.33 grams) equivalent in value to two mahmudi or 200 dinars, first issued by the Safavid Shah Abbas I (reigned 1587–1629) and continuing in use until the 19th century; a money of account derived from this.

notes.text: By the end of the 19th century the value of the dinar had dropped dramatically and the 200-dinar piece had become a copper coin.
